cons: There is a lot of talk about creating growth opportunities and promoting from within, unfortunately there is not a lot of action. Additionally, there is hypocrisy within the organization with leaders and different departments not held to the same standards as others - for example remote work can only be done from the state of Iowa or Nebraska - unless you are in HR then you can work from anywhere in the country.

review_title: Unsafe Staffing Ratios At All Times
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Omaha, NE
pros:
- Most of the patients I worked with were super nice and understanding 
- I met a lot of really awesome coworkers
- Gained a lot of communication skills that will follow me into my next job
- Learned a lot more about healthcare than previous healthcare jobs
cons:
- Unsafe staff ratios hospital wide
- Constant complaining of other staff that would build up negative energy and emotions in others
- You have no downtime, there is always something you need to be doing for twelve hours straight. The only downtime you get is your 30 minute lunch.
- They say you can take 2 fifteen minute breaks but that doesn’t happen 
- A lot of the nurses I personally worked with felt they were above tech related job duties and would not do them
- If there is an emergency with you mid-shift it is almost impossible to leave due to the unsafe staffing ratios.
- This job ruined my mental health

review_title: Horribly mismanaged not safe for patients

review_title: Decent work culture terrible health insurance
pros:
good work culture
always looking to improve the culture
retirement benefits are good
colleagues are amazing
cons: health insurance is garbage. In the last 20 years, I've worked for a number of different employers and Ne Medicine's insurance is terrible. It is expensive and you have to meet a high deductible before copays or coinsurance kicks in. I've never seen an employer offer 3 high deductible plans to choose from and then act like this is competitive. I had to stop getting a beneficial treatment because I couldn't afford the weekly cost of the treatment till I met my deductible. For example, at my previous employer, I paid 50 dollars a month, had no in-network deductible, no primary care copay, 15 dollars behavioral health copay, and 30 dollars specialist copay. I'm paying over 100 dollars per month to have a 2800 dollar dedcutible. I honestly wouldn't have taken they had been more transparent about their health insurance up front.

review_title: Leadership doesn't practice what they preach

Really poor work life balance
No opportunity for training into upper level positions unless you are a "favorite" that leadership wants to promote.
No accountability for leadership not leading and managing their employees.
Subpar pay for their bedside staff.
Treat non leadership level employees like just another disposable resource.

review_title: The employees are treated as expendable GARBAGE.
pros: Not a single thing other than being able to get the vaccine early.
cons:
They charge employees for parking/parking services will boot your car for no reason, cars get broken into all the time because security is a joke, weirdos all around campus make walking to your car at night a dangerous adventure, the bathroom facilities are always broken/out of order or there are homeless people sleeping/bathing in them, nurses received zero hazard pay during covid, staff is leaving in masses because the pay is crap, the benefits suck, and staff is tired of being assaulted.  Communication is also non-existent. 
Nurses have way too many patients.  Too many people in management/leadership who make decisions with ZERO consideration for the results.

pros: nice co-workers and maybe you could have an advantage applying for higher-up healthcare jobs with this experience

pay is $11.50/hour

nurses are always super busy at no fault of their own, but you are left with a patient posing risks to themselves and yourself for many minutes before help arrives

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Omaha, NE
pros:
1. $30 bonus ($30 per hour flat) was brought back for October-March for extra shifts picked up throughout the COVID pandemic, but only after all bonus was taken away throughout the year
2. I like a lot of my team members and staff 
3. Ratios aren't terrible, max of 5-6 on nights and 4 on days (I'm a night nurse)
cons:
1. Benefits are sub par
2. Hours are decently flexible but only if you're quick to schedule 
3. Mandatory overtime (one shift every two weeks) throughout the COVID pandemic
4. I'll never forget when one of the first Zoom meetings during the pandemic we were told we should be "grateful we have a job at all" by higher up leadership
5. The whole "team based nursing" flub where dayshift nurses were taking 5-6 patients with one "extender" nurse who would pass meds for two nurses but not know anything about the patients, it felt unsafe.

pros: Great place to learn as a new nurse. You will have plenty of time to pick up bonus shifts as every unit is very short staffed. Most doctors are quick to respond and actively listen to nursing concerns for their patients.
cons: Management is not very motivating and they make it impossible to transfer within the organization if your floor is short staffed. Management promotes people with little experience which is very unsafe for patients. The leads are always in their office and some days you have no idea who they are since they are never around to help. The acuity of the patients make the burnout rate very high. It seems like the organizations pays more attention on research/patient satisfaction but little attention on employee satisfaction and retention. The benefits suck, for more coverage you have to go to a Nebraska medicine affiliated facility. Also, for nurses week they thank their nurses by giving out a free lip balm donated by metro credit union. They sure know how to treat their employees right.

pros: Pay was good, flexible hours were good. I kept busy.
cons: If you are fresh out of school or don't have a family or social life this is the place for you. Zero work/life balance. Cost of benefits is ridiculous. $12,000 out of pocket before they will pay anything. If you have a chronic medical condition or a child that does, you are out of luck. Taking FMLA or any time off is frowned upon. They are currently trying to get rid of seasoned employees so that they can hire new employee for half the salary. Unreasonable productivity standards. They went with the medical plan that would cost the least for the company, hoping to save $20 million, instead it ended up costing them $16 million in lost revenue. Many employees stopped going to the doctor or taking their meds, causing more health problems in the long run, which means more time off. They operate on a sick/PTO points program that is just ridiculous . Senior management treats the employees like children, they assume you do not understand basic life skills.

review_title: Send this new CEO back to Milwaukee, let's take our hospital back.
pros: Abundance of opportunity if you can stomach the corporate changes that are so detrimental to patient care.
cons: Recent changes due to new CEO have made this a dangerous place for patients, which makes caring for them soul crushing. This used to be an amazing hospital that had the patients concerns and well being front and center. Sadly this is no longer true, in fact the things I see on a daily basis clearly indicate that generating revenue at the expense of patient safety/well being is now the name of the game. As a nurse who has been here 14 years it is horrifying to see how badly quality of patient care has declined. Toxic work environment.

job_title: Patient Senior Access Representative in Omaha, NE
pros: Great benefits. Able to move around.can work as much overtime when allowed.
cons: To management your a work horse. You can be mandated to work shifts. They are not flexible with needing time off. If you call in because you are sick you have to call the manager 4 hours before your scheduled shift. You are also required to record all of your conversations with patients so that the quality department can audit all of yours work done. Supervisors are inconsistent and rude. Once you are trained in one area they will train you in another area and then rotate you around for staffing purposes, so you may be in radiology one day, the next in lab, the next day admit. No communication with staff.

review_title: Great Mission and Care for Patients
job_title: Human Resources Analyst in Omaha, NE
pros: Well recognized in the community, employees really care for patients. Very dynamic campus and a variety of Clinics and Specialties represented. An increased focus on population health management and improving the patient experience. Focused effort on scorecards for providers and tracking quality outcomes for the patients.
cons: Turnover and employee engagement is a problem not being addressed. No exit interviews, so hard to figure out what is causing the turnover. Poor HR Leadership for many years has led to substandard practices, procedures, and technology. Work life balance is preached but no where near the actual expectation. HR doesn't follow/practice it's own policies.

job_title: Clinical Applications Team in Omaha, NE
pros: Working in a non-traditional nursing role, I have felt very supported by my manager and director.  The upward mobility is very real.  This is a phenomenal place to work, both in gaining experience at the bedside, and furthering your career and leadership skills.  Benefits are excellent, and I can see myself retiring from here someday.
cons: So much to learn and do, it's easy to get overwhelmed.  Thank goodness that the preceptors are so dedicated, and there is a great employee round-table every few months that really involves the employees.  The townhall meetings are also an excellent way to feel involved, as are the individual Unit Based Councils.

review_title: Feel Great at the End of the Day
pros: The mission statement is focused around the patients served. There really is a culture of caring for the patient and even their families. The doctors are genuine and I believe that it is more than just a business. As health care changes, more and more academic and private physicians are reaching out to each other to collaborate. I think the nursing staff enjoys having a variety of patient populations to care for.
cons: It takes forever to make any sort of significant change. There are a lot of cogs in the machine. I can't tell if that is due to the fact that the organization is too big or if they are just adverse to change and progressive thinking.

review_title: Exciting things are on the horizon
job_title: IT Systems Manager in Omaha, NE
pros:
Lots of investment in exciting future growth, such as the cancer center.
Starting to see a change in culture to be more data-driven in our decision-making.
People truly care about our patients and providing the best possible care.
cons: Not enough investment in some of our outdated applications that need to be brought to current versions.  There is a huge investment in resources and money towards supporting Epic, which is great (don't get me wrong).  But that seems to distract from the necessary investments in other systems that are very important, as well.

pros: The doctors are the only reason I have remained here
cons: Management is clueless, ignores most of the staff, plays junior high games and is passive-aggressive when staff alerts about a potential issue.

review_title: Paid time off is horrible - just 2 weeks annually during the first few years. Competitors offer over 4 weeks on Day 1
pros: Highly ranked medical institution. Can really learn a lot here, and make a difference to the community. Close to downtown. Growing fast with addition on new facilities. Nice on site fitness facility as well. Good options at the various cafes at the main campus.
cons: Have to pay for parking onsite. The main building is really old - badly needs renovation. The main campus needs more parking.

pros: Community hospital feel, location, pay is slightly higher than average for the area, this hospital was owned by private Doctors and the Nebraska Medical Center but the Med center recently bought out the doctors so it Is growing and has many new resources. I have worked in this facility from the day they opened and love it, and my fellow coworkers.
cons: hospital was owned by private Doctors and the Nebraska Medical Center but the Med center recently bought out the doctors so it Is growing and has many new resources. Some staff are resistant to change and make it difficult to work there.

pros: serious medicine, extraordinary care is the mission, and we are moving closer to achieving it every day.  We have an internationally acclaimed transplant program, US News and World report rated us in the top 50 hospitals for cancer and brain medicine, most doctors in NE are trained in our medical school.  If you have a broken leg, you can go somewhere else to get treated, if your doctor has given up or doesn't know what to do, he or she should send you here.  Employees rate thier satisfaction as 89.5%.  Not bad for a non-profit in the poor part of town.
cons: change occurrs slowly with so many bosses and approvals in the University system

review_title: Excellent place to work. Always on the edge of what's next.
pros:
* Very good, competitive compensation. 
* Benefits grow with your length of time in the organization.
* As a teaching institution we are always learning new techniques, medicines and protocols; pushing the edge of what is known and how best to treat patients. 
* Biocontainment Unit - one of only 3 in the U.S. 
* World-class physicians who care.
* Team work is practiced, not just a concept.
* Employees valued from bottom to top.
* Always striving to improve.
* Parking and transportation alternatives being implemented.
cons:
* Large, inner-city campus with parking that is spread out. 
* Having to pay to park.

pros: Most of my coworkers are great to work with and they always have your back which is a blessing.
cons: Management is a joke. Our mission statement to give extroidinary care is just a statement to get people in the door. We are over worked and underappreciated. Of you don't work enough you are going to be getting a visit from somebody telling you to pick up the pace.it doesn't matter that you have a critical or high maintenance patient that is requiring a lot of work, you are told you will just have to sick it up and work faster

pros: The benefits are decent and my co-workers are good to work with. The work environment is ok and I do like my actual job.
cons: There is more work to do than what can be accomplished. Numbers have increased but there has not been a change in the number of workers to do that work. New hires are paid more than employees who have been there for the same of "work experience". In my area there is no room for advancement, but that is not true for all positions within the hospital.

pros: Decent facility with moderately flexible hours/shifts. They do care about both employee and patient safety.
cons: Unfortunately toxic leadership has makes decisions based on company political and personal views causing downstream problems for the actual workers. If you want to work here be fore warned that the lab/path leaders do not care about their workers, their bottom line is the dollar bill. If you can deal with that than you'll survive. They finally have started to force their managers to go to leadership training after years of poor managerial reviews.

pros: I believe they really care about their employees.  There is an employee recognition program to recognize people who you feel have been going above and beyond.  Holiday parties are always great to attend, as well as gifts for every employee at christmas time.
cons: I think sometimes, big government, gets in the way of how the departments operate.  Managers who don't even work in the department are changing things; however, they don't even know it works and should be getting more info from the people who are there every day.

pros: I love my surgeons and the people I work with, we also do some pretty amazing stuff
cons: The upper management and CEO keep taking away special bonuses we used to get, they also don't seem to value the people that have been around for a long time. I also feel that they are more concerned about money that making sure we have staff to give quality care to our patients. It gets frustrating when most of the CEO's and lower have a business degree and don't really know anything about patient care. for the 5 years that I was a surgical tech and certified I really didn't feel valued even though I can scrub most any case.

pros: Nebraska Medicine is on the cutting edge of medical science and does provide good medical care to their patients.
cons:
Senior management does not look at the organization as a hospital, but a money-making machine. The people at the top are more likely to take actions that will benefit their wallets instead of what would make the organization a better company for which to work. More than once the CHCO declared he wanted to make the organization the best place to work in Omaha, Nebraska, the US, etc. -- but he has been able to persuade his colleagues to make necessary changes to increase workplace morale which is certainly low. 
They proclaim a work-life balance, but I was working 60 hours a week just to keep up with my work load and worked weekends; all these extra hours were unpaid due to my employment status. 

While I was working for free, other employee groups were getting millions of dollars thrown at them so they wouldn't walk off the job.

This organization preaches "Serious Medicine, Extraordinary Care" but they hire people who care more about the size of their paychecks than the patients they were hired to help.

Nebraska Med is using valuable real estate to build a hotel that the CEO himself said  "would not be in the price range of most of our patients" -- this all the while other hospitals in the area have started to offer free housing to their patients who have to come in from out of town for treatments.

review_title: Hard to imagine working somewhere else
job_title: Revenue Cycle Training/QA Associate in Omaha, NE
pros:
Strong leadership in the Revenue Cycle provides opportunities for entry level employees to grow in their roles and seek advancement. Performance expectations are clear making it easy for staff to set and obtain personal goals. Tools such  as training, quality audits and production guidelines help staff keep tabs on their own performance giving them the best chance to grow through accountability.

On a more global level, the senior leadership walks the walk when it comes to honest, straight forward communication.
cons: As with most large companies,  some areas have stronger cultures than others. This can make it hard to work across department lines.

job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Omaha, NE
pros: I've been working for Ne Med for about 9 Months.   The hours and working environment are excellent.  Benefits and time off are generous.
cons: Parking on Main campus is difficult.   Initially you may have to park far away from your work area.   However If you find alternatives like carpooling and bus transportation it is covered by the company.

pros: We take care of very sick patients; which means we also do very special surgeries and treatments that you can only receive at NMC. Transplants, cancer treatment and reconstructive surgery and several more unique experiences.
cons: Staff is extremely under paid and over worked. Staff that have worked for company several years make the same as a new hire grad. They don't appreciate employees who have stayed with company. Benefits are horrible and the only employer in omaha where you must pay to park in their lot. Lowest price is $23 a month and it's almost a mile away from hospital entrance.

review_title: Sad to see our great hospital stop caring about their employees.
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Omaha, NE
pros: Great co-workers, plenty of opportunities to change floors after one year on current floor.
cons: Unappreciated, undervalued, underpaid and now bonuses have been decreased significantly. Staffing is poor and no hiring of ancillary staff in sight. More and more is being expected from the nurses to compensate for other employees jobs that are being eliminated. Very stressful acuity levels.

pros: Extremely compassionate, passionate people work here who take great pride in caring for some of the sickest patients in the region.  The frontline people (clinical and non-clinical) make this place's potential extremely exciting.
cons: Focused on expansion while lacking resource investment (people, processes, & technology).  Frequently, there is poor follow through on initiatives & a seemingly lack of true strategic vision.  Necessary changes are frustratingly slow to realize - lots of bureaucracy.

review_title: Great experience but at a cost
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Omaha, NE
pros: Great place to gain experience. Very diverse patient population with patients coming in from surrounding states as well. Wonderful coworkers who are always willing to help.
cons: Poor communication with management. Lots of turnover on a unit basis, many stay within the system but transfer to different areas. Understaffed, be prepared to take on more call and weekends/holidays than they tell you (you won't have much of a social life). Insurance benefits are "just ok", you are probably better off using your spouse's insurance.

review_title: Good job, but we can do better
pros: The rewards you get from impoving patients lives, you really do feel like you get to make a difference in the lives of the patients you care for.
cons: Lack of employee knowledge about programs out there to recognize other employees for work that goes above and beyond. Some difficulty it getting scheduling accomplished.

pros: Great employees, good benefits, access to up to date technology, lots of opportunities for growth and development. Market analysis of compensation levels are done on a regular basis with increases in pay to stay competitive within the market.
cons: Staff shortages stretch employees and increase stress levels. Continuous increases in job requirements to increase safety but this puts additional stress on employees. Things move slowly, approval of additional positions, hiring etc. Long wait times for appointments at times=unhappy patients.

review_title: Good company to work for with good benefits.
pros: Positive work environment for the most part. Leadership was supportive & Executive Leader was visible in the company & friendly to employees.
cons: Parking is an issue on the huge campus. Salary was fair but increases were slow. Slow responses from HR on advancement opportunities.

review_title: Horrible. Run like hell & don't look back. Don't work here.
pros: The benefits *were* good, but UNMC is changing to a lesser health care plan that is terrible.
cons:
- No accountability for management: management behaves as they like, often disregarding employment law as they please and there's no repercussions. The EEOC will have a field day once enough people complain. Worse yet, senior management and employee relations protect managers instead of taking appropriate corrective actions.
- No work/life balance.
- Complete abuse of "other tasks as requested" to the point of being obscenely abusive.
- Lousy opportunity to advance.
- The rules apply to some but not to others.
- You have to pay to park.
- Terrible annual raises.
- No remuneration for going above & beyond or completion of special projects.
- Hideous internal politics akin to a snake pit or a shark tank.
- Terrible morale.
- Uncaring and malicious Management.
- "Do as I say and not as I do" and "the rules don't apply to me" attitude is out of control with management (I had a member of management tell me that numerous times).
- Favoritism exists and thrives at UNMC - if you kiss enough butt you will get far. If you are a hard worker but refuse to kiss butt, you will never get anywhere.
- Micromanagement and hovering managers waiting like a cat to pounce the first time you do anything not to their liking.
- Company Culture is a nightmare - It's a broken, glaringly flawed culture that refuses to admit it is broken but stubbornly takes the stance of "well this is how we've always done it." This is why the organization is hemorrhaging money and in the terrible shape it's in.
- Too many Managers - There are so many managers, each doing their own thing instead of focusing on working together that it is chaos. Nobody in management is on the same page and the communication gap is horrific. The Right hand has no idea what the Left hand is doing.
- The budget cuts impact the workers hardest while managers continue to get their annual stipend bonuses that equal more than some full time employees make pre-tax.
- Incompetent Managers - If you have no leadership capacities or people skills, you'll be in management in no time.
- Discrimination & Harassment out of control from management.
- Overbearing management.
- Overworked with huge work loads and no appreciation at all for success.
- No job security. 
- Managers don't want to listen.
- Managers don't want to have his/her opinions and ideas challenged but will challenge everybody else.
- It's the Good Old Boy's Club at UNMC. Prepare for a time travel experience to the days of 1950's management style.

review_title: It's been a good place to work.
pros: Great place to cover a wide spectrum of stuff. Not stuck doing one thing or managing one type of system. You can get your hands in things like storage, systems, different OS's, etc. Ability to get training has been no problem and have gotten lots of it.
cons: None really to speak of other than people who grumble that it's a terrible place.

review_title: Fantastic company, dedicated to patient care
pros: Proffesion environment, Senior management swift and proactive, well respected in the community, culture of self improvement
cons: Long hours, benefits are middle of the road, management tends to "helicopter" over you looking for feedback or metrics in places that are not problem areas, the worst parking situation I've experienced in my life

review_title: HR has little regard for employment laws, morale continues to sharply decline.
pros: Enjoy our patients and their families. Great coworkers.
cons: Several  types of discrimination that people in my department are aware of and now formal complaints have surfaced.

pros: I loved the work environment everyone was nice, kind, and helpful to everyone. The pay was also good.
cons: I took a job working Evs thinking that I can do a job transver as a cna I have 4 years experience but never happened nobody called me. I believe that I put in four different job transfer application for cna position.  I worked the casual but was working 24 hrs a week.

pros: You are able to obtain and maintain skills because of the depth of scans done everyday.
cons: Management sees you as a number.  Everyone is replaceable.  There is never any consideration to how busy we are and if we ever get a lunch/bathroom break.

pros: Lots of hours available. Helping patients.
cons: Short staffed. Not appreciated. Terrible managers that don't care. Drama. Employees that have no work ethic.  Discipline hard workers and let's everyone else slide who doesn't work and slacks off. Changes are never made. No support. Bad managing skills. The managers are running employees out of the door.

review_title: Great for college unless going into nursing, than great career
pros:
Great atmosphere with great co-workers. 
Very flexible hours
A great college job. I highly recommend if going to college
cons: For the amount of work assigned, the pay is not as high as expected and the duties and roles are very minimal. Not a lot of growth unless your en-route to be a nurse

pros: Dealing and helping patients, pharmacists are helpful,
cons: The Director thinks he  is a godfather, Never wants to be contradicted and if you do you will be taken aside and told your uneducated and unqualified. No one likes him but the hospital puts his ego first for the money he makes for them.

job_title: Patient Care Tech in Omaha, NE
pros: Great place to have on your resume,management seems friendly,40% off schooling at clarkson,transfer to other positions in 6 months
cons: Buying your own uniforms,Long hours ,Working Holidays(day before and after for most),snobby nurses ,Fast Paced 24/7,constant change you can move floors mid shift due to staffing or amount of patients on your floor

review_title: New employee, but so far great experience!
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Omaha, NE
pros: Nebraska Medicine offers a great variety of benefits available for full and part time employees working over 20 hours a week.
cons: Although benefits are offered, they seem to be at higher premiums than other area companies. Health insurance high deductible plan is still expensive.

pros: Wonderful colleagues, caring leadership, unmatched industry expertise, good work/life balance, good benefits package
cons: The company has had a lot of leadership transition, which created unease for some as the culture and expectations changed- however, change isn't always a bad thing and the organization is on the right track.

pros: Flexible Schedule.Work-Life Balance. Fair Compensation. opportunities to increase your knowledge in your current job through training and further education given time to learn current processes
cons: Slow in embracing change - but the organization is catching

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Omaha, NE
pros: I like the twelve hours shifts or eight-hour shift option. They give differentials for overnights, weekends, and float pool.
cons: I have been employed and earned awards and nominations but have not received any bonus or raise since I started my employment almost two years ago.

pros: Amazing doctors and coworkers. Many learning opportunities. Always available to pick up extra shifts.
cons: Not a big gap between starting wage as nurse and cap salary as a nurse. Since COVID, there is no more incentive shifts which probably the biggest con.

review_title: Working at The Nebraska Medical Center
pros: Great work environment! This move very face paced and get done quick and efficiently.
cons: I do not have much to to say in the way of cons other than on occasion things tend to go a little bit slower and the hospital is understaffed.

pros: Innovative healthcare. Brand new cancer center being built.
cons: Top heavy on "leadership" and layers of management who have meetings about meetings while little is done to empower or support employees.

pros: Great work, great people, great technology.  Love the variety and the opportunity to make a difference in the work that I do
cons: I really can't think of anything, other than maybe the parking can be kind of tough

pros:
* Motivated team members
* Highly meaningful job
* Passionate workplace
* Market competitive compensation
* Room for career growth
* Strong leadership
* A lot of smart people doing a lot of cool stuff!
cons: * Death by meetings (at times)

pros: A steady paycheck and health insurance.
cons: Managed by Sodexo but employed by the hospital. A grotesque conflict of interest with an emphasis on profit.

pros: The company as a whole is good to work for. They recognize employees, give tuition reimbursement, and have decent benefits.
cons: The department I work in is a joke. The manager doesn't respond to emails, nothing ever changes, and nobody cares.

pros: Great environment, great team. Love the technology and tools.  Great opportunities for advancement, senior management gets it
cons: Compensation is okay.  HR seems to want to pinch pennies.

job_title: Certified Nurse Assistant in Omaha, NE
pros:
Health Insurance, Dental and Vision prorated by Simply Well. 
On site food vendors.
cons:
Poor staffing, not enough nurses/care techs per unit.
Terrible management. 
Terrible salary/hourly wages.

review_title: Operating Room & Breast Feeding mothers beware
pros: Unique surgeries, job security, great place to build experience
cons: sterile processing is awful, bullying, favoritism, inadequate lactation and pumping accommodations

pros: Competitive pay, room for growth, good management, cutting-edge patient care.
cons: Parking (although it is improving), health benefits could be a bit better.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Omaha, NE
pros: Patients and peers are great
cons: Management lazy and inept, do not even respond when staff brings concerns for patient care and safety.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Omaha, NE
pros: Advanced evolution in care, personal growth, reputation
cons: Poor management and lack of support of ancillary staff, benefits, consistently fail to fulfill promise, minimal value of tenured employees.

pros: great organization to work for, lots of complex high acuity patients
cons: lack of magement support, high turn over, lack of loyalty towards internal promotions

job_title: Associate Clinic Manager in Omaha, NE
pros: Leadership tries to work on culture
cons: at the end of the day it is about the money and no loyalty to the staff whatsoever.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Omaha, NE
pros: flexible scheduling, decent pay, and able to balance school with this job
cons: patient to staff ratio too high

job_title: Vascular Access Specialist in Omaha, NE
pros: Worked with the smartest healthcare professionals in the nation.
cons: Pay wasn’t great, but the job was phenomenal.  Very pleased.

pros: Great pay, good benefits.  Awesome culture
cons: Parking stinks, and is expensive.  Cafeteria gets too busy for the short lunch breaks.

pros: A lot of opportunities for those starting their careers
cons: Too business-focused and not enough compassion or ethics

job_title: Psychiatric Social Worker in Omaha, NE
pros: Amazing learning environment to work in
cons: Their employees work very hard

pros:
Label of being number one hospital in the state 

Teaching facility offers tuition reduction programs
cons:
No transparency 
Poor communication between leadership and staff

pros: Job growth opportunity is good.
cons: As a larger institution, there is a fair amount of administrative hurdles to get change in place.

pros: Education opportunities, location, magnet status
cons: Poor benefits and below average compensation

job_title: Food Service Associate in Omaha, NE
pros: Good benefit and higher wages
cons: Longer shift and many  task to do

job_title: Product Supply Lead in Omaha, NE
pros: CEO, job security, pay, support
cons: There are no cons to report

job_title: Emergency Services Technician in Omaha, NE
pros: Great people and amazing experiences working in the ER
cons:
very busy ER 
parking can be a little difficult

pros: good benefits, good training. Decent pay
cons: depending on what department you schedule for you could be on the phone non stop

pros: Job opportunties, academic learning environment, friendly docs
cons: Constant changes, high expectations

job_title: Patient Access Senior Associate in Omaha, NE
pros: great pay, easy job, excellent co workers
cons: essential staffing, customer service, limited advancement in the department

job_title: Clinical Study Associate in Omaha, NE
pros: Great environment to work in, leading in new research
cons: Not many - parking not great

pros: Learn a lot, great coworkers
cons: Large institution and can easily get lost in the institution.

pros: Great place to work.  Lots of opprotunity.
cons: PARKING.  Need to at least bring back the shuttle service.

pros: Plenty of opportunities to advance your career
cons: Too many managers that are not engaged with their staff.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Omaha, NE
pros:
Self scheduling 
Every other weekend
Nice staff

Short staffing
Floating a lot 
Some times no breaks

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Omaha, NE
pros: Comp pay, benefits, management, coworkers, culture
cons: monotonous at times but can be rather stressful,

pros: Good opportunities, focused on education
cons: Large company, can feel like a number

pros: Great company to work for during pandemic
cons: Definitely Lacks diversity and inclusiveness

pros: Very ill patients and lots to learn
cons: Parking is awful, almost too big

pros: Meeting nice patients and their families.
cons: No advancement opportunities, unprofessional management, favortism, disorganized, negatism, overworked and underpaid, worst management ever!

job_title: Product Supply Associate in Omaha, NE
pros: GOOD PAY, great nursing staff
